data.title: [Emscripten/Javascript] Missing path slashes on windows during emscripten linking.
data.body:
Windows 10 Pro Insider Preview Build 16215.rs_prerelease.170603
Current godot master branch version

I tried to build the godot binary using the steps detailed in the web build instructions in the "latest" version of the documentation. The compilation works fine, aside from warnings, but it can't find the .bc files for linking because the path it looks in has all the slashes removed. Here's the relevant output:

```
emcc @c:\users\cjb86\appdata\local\temp\tmp_ojvbg.lnk
C:/Emscripten/clang/e1.37.9_64bit\llvm-link: C:Userscjb86ROAGOgodotmodulesregister_module_types.javascript.opt.bc: error: Could not open input file: no such file or directory
C:/Emscripten/clang/e1.37.9_64bit\llvm-link: error loading file 'C:Userscjb86ROAGOgodotmodulesregister_module_types.javascript.opt.bc'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Emscripten\emscripten\1.35.0\\emcc", line 1201, in <module>
    shared.Building.link(linker_inputs, specified_target)
  File "C:\Emscripten\emscripten\1.35.0\tools\shared.py", line 1432, in link
    assert os.path.exists(target) and (output is None or 'Could not open input file' not in output), 'Linking error: ' + output
AssertionError: Linking error:
scons: *** [modules\libmodules.javascript.opt.bc] Error 1
scons: building terminated because of errors.
```


Steps to reproduce:

1) Setup the javascript build prerequisites according to the guide. ( http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/development/compiling/compiling_for_web.html )
2) Run "scons platform=javascript tools=no target=release" in powershell in the root godot directory.
3) Observe link error.

data.title: AnimationPlayer: Keyframing doesn't work
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux, Godot 3 master

**Issue description:**

Setting keyframes to animate objects currently doesn't seem to work in Godot 3. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Set up a simple scene with an AnimationPlayer
2. Add a new animation and try to animate a sprite (e.g position) using keyframes
3. The properties of the previous keyframes are ignored (hence no animation)


**Link to minimal example project:**
The following example works in Godot 2.1.3 but not in Godot 3:

![godot_anim](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7927471/27502470-92c03076-5874-11e7-90fb-b5f54dedaea7.gif)

data.title: Legible output for typeof()
data.body:
Currently, `typeof()` returns an integer and you have to look at the global scope to see what it means. 

It would be better for it to return something that is human-readable.

data.title: GL error spam when using a viewport (Sampler object 0 is bound to non-depth texture 0) [nvidia, Linux]
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 master Linux
GTX 770 with nvidia driver 381.22

**Issue description:**
Spam of "mesege" in output window and this error in debug:
```
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL	Type: Undefined behaviorID: 131222	Severity: Medium	Message: Program undefined behavior warning: Sampler object 0 is bound to non-depth texture 0, yet it is used with a program that uses a shadow sampler. This is undefined behavior.
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Create a simple scene with a viewport containing a 3D scene

**Link to minimal example project:**
[viewport-test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1098479/viewport-test.zip)

data.title: docs: Correct xform descriptions in class_basis
Bad separation of KinematicBody2D move against LineShape2D
data.body:
**Godot version: 2.1.3**


**Issue description:**
Moving a KinematicBody2D (as in `move`) against a solid body with a LineShape2D, seems to not separate the body correctly leading to continuous collisions.
![badkb-line](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10215987/27481388-b74d838a-57f2-11e7-9994-73c8b17a5a56.gif)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Move a KinematicBody2D against a line and try to move it again in the opposite direction.
Forcing a separation (with `set_pos`) lead to the correct behaviour.


**Link to minimal example project:**
[kb2dbadlineseparation.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1097690/kb2dbadlineseparation.zip)

Probably related to this #7920 ?

data.title: [Feature Request] Disable and Enable Collision of a CollisionShape2d
data.body:
An checkbox in the node inspector and a new method for CollisionShape2d and 3d maybe so you can disable and enable the collision in runtime and not deleting it and re instancing it to a scene. 

For example an attack animation where the hitbox collision is enabled in certain frames or a wall/door where the collision is disabled or enabled pressing a button

EDIT: with disable collision I mean It disables all kind of information that can be send and received. Not only for colliding with another body that makes it to stop moving

data.title: The behavior of KinematicBody2D is not consistent
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
godot 2.1.3

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
it's a very simple update method that make a body move on the ground and when it hit a wall, it will move in the opposite direction. It works sometimes.  But sometimes it will not  bounce back when hit a wall, it will just stop by the wall. 
```gdscript
func _fixed_process(delta):
	vel.y += 2000 * delta
	var motion = move(vel * delta)
	if is_colliding():
		var normal = get_collision_normal()
		if normal.x != 0:
			vel.x = -vel.x
		else:
			vel.y = 0
		motion = normal.slide(motion)
		move(motion)
```
**Steps to reproduce:**


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

<sub>bugsquad edit: reformatted script.</sub>

data.title: Image: Fix wrong method DEFVAL
AnimationPlayer Node but simplier only for Sprite Animations
data.body:
Basically an AnimatedSprite node + keyframing everything and tracks, specially keyframing a function in a certain frame of the animation or an CollisionShape for hitbox purpose

Spritesheets or multiple image sprites are way simplier, it only needs duration of animation, and if it needs to loop or not. but doing this in the AnimationPlayer node its very complicated because you have put first the timeline length, the step between frames and at this point youre just guessing and trying every number so your animation looks good.

AnimationPlayer is excellent for separated part characters but not so good for simple sprite animations if you want to use its amazing features.

data.title: [Feature Request] Flip horizontally and vertically feature for all Body2d nodes
data.body:
New methods like `set_flip_h( bool flip_h)` and `set_flip_v( bool flip_v)` and checkbox in node inspector for KinematicBody2d, StaticBody2d and maybe RigidBody2d(I don't think so)

```
if flip_h == true:
		set_scale(Vector2(-1,1))
	else:
		set_scale(Vector2(1,1))
```

so everything that's inside a Body2d will flip too, like a gun facing left turns to the right or the CollisionShape made in a specific position

data.title: Float rounding and precision
data.body:
Windows 7, Godot 2.1.3.0 Steam version

Why are my floats here being automatically rounded? Is this intended behaviour? 
Using them as-is or float()ing them produces the same, rounded, result.
How can I create accurate Vector2s from these array values?


	var points = [[ -7641742.9734278414, -6891032.3691751538 ], 
	[ -7640489.5277312668, -6891460.7849851009 ], 
	[ -7618662.6263543591, -6893579.913525274 ], 
	[ -7591951.2935277065, -6892344.3927164907 ]]
	
	var vec2array = Vector2Array()
	var vec2farray = Vector2Array()
	
	for i in range(0, points.size()):
		vec2array.append(Vector2(points[i][0], points[i][1]))
		vec2farray.append(Vector2(float(points[i][0]), float(points[i][1])))
		
	print("v2 array: ", vec2array)
	print("v2 f array: ", vec2farray)

Console output:
```
v2 array: [(-7641743, -6891032.5), (-7640489.5, -6891461), (-7618662.5, -6893580), (-7591951.5, -6892344.5)]
v2 f array: [(-7641743, -6891032.5), (-7640489.5, -6891461), (-7618662.5, -6893580), (-7591951.5, -6892344.5)]
```

data.title: Code signing on Mac OS X
data.body:
Just capturing this as we briefly discussed this on IRC today. 

Mac OS X is getting stricter when it comes to deploying applications. Ever since the introduction of gatekeeper in OS X 10.9, and the rules being more strictly enforced since OS X 10.11 deploying an application on Mac OS X requires code signing to be effortless.

The approach Godot currently uses to deploy a zipped application bundle results in Mac OS X marking the application as quarantined after unzipping.

You can work around this by either turning off gatekeeper, manually clearing the quarantine flag, or after Mac OS X instructs you to do so, going to System Preferences->Security and selecting run anyway (this last option doesn't always work consistently I've found). 

The nicer option would be to properly code sign the application. Apple no longer requires you to pay a $100 yearly fee to code sign unless you are deploying through the Apple store but the code signing process is only available on Mac OS X (though I have read somewhere you can export the signature as PKCS12 and apply the code signing on windows, worth investigating).

On OSX, provided the signatures are installed in your keychain you can simply use the [codesign](https://developer.apple.com/legacy/library/documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man1/codesign.1.html) command.

The other thing that was mentioned was to enabling creating a DMG instead of ZIP if we're running on Mac OS X and only use ZIP when exporting on another platform.

data.title: Osx export
data.body:
I reimplemented the OSX export code that had been disabled, I think I got it pretty much working as it should. It obviously needs a fresh ios.zip file with proper binaries in it.

@reduz the only thing I wasn't sure about was the get_preset_features which currently doesn't return anything. I'm assuming that it should be returning info about what is supported or something?

I also fixed a bug with the error not being hidden once there is no more error. 

This should resolve #9243 

Note that we did have a discussion on IRC about adding code signing logic and creating a DMG instead of ZIP if you're on Mac. I have not had time to look into that.
Important to note is that since 10.9 gatekeeper has become stricter in accepting non code signed applications and that unzipping an application that has not been code signed will be marked as quarantined and thus won't run.

To find out if your app is marked for quarantine you can run:
xattr godot.app
And to clear:
xattr -d com.quarantine.apple godot.app

But that is hardly something you would want your users to deal with. I'll raise a separate issue for these.

data.title: Normalmap Importing (s3tc.stex) not working on certain Normal Map Textures in 3D graphics.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

3.0 Alpha Source Code Build, Windows 10 Pro, Wacom Cintiq Companion 2

**Issue description:**

I was trying to import a normalmap onto an object to test the PBR shading, but unfortunately, somewhere during the import process, the s3tc.stex didn't import the texture the right way...

This link shows a screenshot with cut pieces attached of what I am talking about
![normal_error_demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27427226-0bcd1bb0-56f3-11e7-987e-16efd341db21.png)


The engine somehow hasn't read or imported the normalmap correctly and now the object is completely glitched. In the resource tab the imported normalmap looks glitched in the preview, and the inspector editor isn't loading the normalmap texture.

**Steps to reproduce:**

I've included the albedo, roughness, rim, and normalmap textures so then you can see if you're seeing the same problem. 

1. In an empty scene, create a WorldEnvironment Node and add a panorama .exr or .hdr texture.
2. Add a Mesh Instance Node and create either a cube, cylinder, or etc in the "Mesh" option.
3. Create a SpatialMaterial in the Materials slot, and start adding the attached textures to the object.

Let me know if you're having the same problem, because I think either I did something wrong with the normalmapping or that the import process needs a tweak for normalmapping.

![powerpost_rim](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27427171-e51f9736-56f2-11e7-8c6a-7798633f25bd.png)
![powerpost_roughness](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27427172-e521edec-56f2-11e7-9930-69df4108cf33.png)
![powerpost_albedo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27427174-e523a6dc-56f2-11e7-8b71-1c8bd24ef475.png)
![powerpost_normal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5027750/27427173-e52328ec-56f2-11e7-8610-d5905bfccddd.png)

data.title: NormalMaps (NORMAL) not working on Tilesets
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux 64bit Ubuntu 16.04 - Godot 3.0 alpha commit f27d2a3355b8c577fccd961d28dd6085887623c2

**Issue description:**
When creating the tiles for a tilemap, every Sprite has a "Texture" and a "Normal Map" but the lights ignore them set on the Sprite GUI dropdowns, save teh scene and convert to Tileset

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a new scene, create the tiles for a tilemap (Sprites), every Sprite has a "Texture" and a "Normal Map", save the scene and convert to Tileset, now use the tileset on another scene with Light2D.
The Light2D works like only the Texture is set and no Normal Map is set
Even tried creating a shaderMaterial for the tiles and setting NORMAL on the fragment, also is ignored when used as Tileset.

data.title: Inverse lifetime draw order option for Particles/Particles2D
data.body:
**Godot version: 3**

On Particles and Particles2D, Draw order "lifetime" draws older particles first and younger particles stay on top, an option to set the inverse order as "lifetime" could be useful for emission effects that face the screen (in fact, it may be more useful than lifetime and index draw orders for general use).
